questions.q: What is a thread?
questions.explanation: A thread is the smallest unit of execution within a process; it's 'lightweight' because it shares resources with other threads.
options: A lightweight process within a process

questions.q: Threads within the same process share:
questions.explanation: While each thread has its own stack and registers, they all share the same memory (code and data) of the parent process.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of multithreading?
questions.explanation: Multithreading doesn't inherently increase security; in fact, shared memory can sometimes make it harder to protect data.

questions.q: In a multithreaded server, when a request arrives, the server:
questions.explanation: Creating a new thread is much faster than creating a whole new process to handle a request.

questions.q: Which term refers to performing multiple tasks simultaneously on multiple cores?
questions.explanation: Parallelism is doing multiple things at the exact same time; Concurrency is making progress on multiple things over time.

questions.q: Data parallelism refers to:
questions.explanation: This is like giving 4 people the same math problem but different numbers to work on simultaneously.
options: Same operation on subsets of data across cores

questions.q: Amdahl's Law is used to predict:
questions.explanation: It calculates the maximum improvement you can get by adding more CPUs to a program that has a serial portion.

questions.q: User threads are managed by:
questions.explanation: User threads are handled by a library (like Pthreads) without the OS kernel being involved.

questions.q: Which threading model maps many user threads to one kernel thread?
questions.explanation: The Many-to-One model handles all threads via a single kernel entry; if one blocks, they all block.

questions.q: In the One-to-One threading model, each user thread maps to:
questions.explanation: Every user thread created results in a corresponding kernel thread being created.

questions.q: Which operating system uses the One-to-One threading model?
questions.explanation: Modern Windows and Linux systems primarily use the One-to-One model for better performance.

questions.q: The Many-to-Many model allows:
questions.explanation: It multiplexes many user-level threads onto a smaller or equal number of kernel threads.
options: One user thread per kernel thread
Many user threads to many kernel threads

questions.q: Pthreads is a thread API standard for:
questions.explanation: POSIX threads (Pthreads) is the standard for Linux, Solaris, and other UNIX systems.

questions.q: In Pthreads, which function creates a thread?
questions.explanation: The name clearly defines its purpose: creating a new thread of execution.

questions.q: Which Windows function creates a thread?
questions.explanation: Windows uses CreateThread() for threads and CreateProcess() for entire programs.

questions.q: Java threads are managed by:
questions.explanation: The JVM handles thread creation and management across different operating systems.

questions.q: Implicit threading is managed by:
questions.explanation: The programmer identifies 'what' should be parallel, and the library/compiler decides 'how' to run the threads.

questions.q: Which is NOT an implicit threading method?
questions.explanation: Pthreads is explicit; the programmer must manually create and manage every thread.

questions.q: A thread pool is used to:
questions.explanation: A pool keeps threads ready for use, preventing the system from being overwhelmed by too many threads.

questions.q: OpenMP is used for:
questions.explanation: OpenMP uses directives to make C/C++ code run in parallel on shared-memory systems.

questions.q: Grand Central Dispatch is associated with:
questions.explanation: GCD is a technology developed by Apple for macOS and iOS.

questions.q: In a multithreaded program, fork() may:
questions.explanation: Most modern UNIX systems provide a version of fork that only copies the thread that called it.

questions.q: Signals in UNIX are used to:
questions.explanation: Signals are like software interrupts that tell a process something happened (like Ctrl+C).

questions.q: Thread cancellation types include:
questions.explanation: Asynchronous kills the thread instantly; deferred lets the thread finish its current task safely.

questions.q: Thread-Local Storage (TLS) is used to:
questions.explanation: TLS allows a thread to have its own unique variables that aren't shared with other threads.
options: Give each thread its own copy of data

questions.q: Scheduler activations are used in which threading model?
questions.explanation: They help the kernel communicate with the thread library to manage LWPs efficiently.

questions.q: Lightweight Process (LWP) acts as:
questions.explanation: An LWP is a data structure that sits between user threads and kernel threads.

questions.q: Windows threads use which mapping model?
questions.explanation: Windows creates a kernel thread for every user thread.

questions.q: In Windows, the thread environment block (TEB) stores:
questions.explanation: The TEB is a user-space structure containing the thread's local data.

questions.q: Linux uses which system call to create threads?
questions.explanation: clone() is powerful because it allows the programmer to choose exactly what resources to share.

questions.q: The clone() system call in Linux can share:
questions.explanation: The flags passed to clone() determine how much the parent and child share.

questions.q: Concurrency is possible on:
questions.explanation: Concurrency just means tasks overlap in time; on a single core, this is done by switching back and forth fast.

questions.q: Parallelism is possible on:
questions.explanation: Parallelism requires multiple hardware units (cores) to do two things at the exact same instant.

questions.q: Which is NOT a challenge in multicore programming?
questions.explanation: Clock speed is a hardware trait; it isn't a programming challenge like splitting data is.

questions.q: Task parallelism refers to:
questions.explanation: This is like having one person cook while another person cleans the dishes at the same time.
options: Same task on multiple data sets

questions.q: The primary thread libraries mentioned are:
questions.explanation: These are the three most common standard APIs for thread management.
options: C threads, Python threads, Ruby threads
Kernel threads, system threads, user threads
Hard threads, soft threads, light threads

questions.q: In the Many-to-One model, if one thread blocks:
questions.explanation: Since the kernel only sees one thread, if that one thread waits for I/O, the entire process is put to sleep.

questions.q: The Two-level model is similar to:
questions.explanation: It's a variation of Many-to-Many that also allows a user thread to be bound strictly to a kernel thread.

questions.q: A thread library can be implemented in:
questions.explanation: Libraries can either be purely user-level or utilize OS kernel support.

questions.q: Pthreads is a:
questions.explanation: It defines the 'behavior' required; different OSes might implement that behavior differently.

questions.q: In the Pthreads example, pthread_join() is used to:
questions.explanation: It's used to synchronize; the main thread waits at this point until the child thread is done.
options: Wait for a thread to finish

questions.q: Java threads are created by implementing:
questions.explanation: The Runnable interface is the standard way to define the code that a thread will run.

questions.q: OpenMP uses ________ to define parallel regions.
questions.explanation: It uses #pragma directives to tell the compiler which parts of the code to parallelize.

questions.q: Grand Central Dispatch uses ________ to encapsulate work.
questions.explanation: Blocks (chunks of code) are submitted to dispatch queues to be executed.

questions.q: Serial dispatch queues in GCD process blocks in:
questions.explanation: First-In, First-Out; tasks are completed in the exact order they are added to the queue.

questions.q: In thread cancellation, deferred cancellation allows the thread to:
questions.explanation: This is safer because the thread can clean up resources before it stops.
options: Check for cancellation at specific points

questions.q: Thread-Local Storage is similar to:
questions.explanation: It acts like a static variable but its value is unique to each individual thread.

questions.q: Scheduler activations use ________ to communicate between kernel and thread library.
questions.explanation: Upcalls allow the kernel to tell the user-level thread library about events like a thread blocking.

questions.q: Windows thread data structures include:
questions.explanation: ETHREAD (Executive Thread), KTHREAD (Kernel Thread), and TEB (Thread Environment Block) are the specific names used in Windows.

questions.q: Linux threads are referred to as:
questions.explanation: In Linux, the kernel doesn't distinguish much between processes and threads; it calls them both 'tasks'.
